Chapter . Zotero
Zotero is a free tool to help you collect, organize and share research.

Zotero has been consoldiated into a single software that is compatible with all browsers via the Zotero Connector plugin.
Chapter . Zotero Connector
Zotero Connector is a browser plugin that integrates Zotero into your web browser and helps you save content to your Zotero library.

Zotero works seamlessly with Windows. The following steps will show you how to download and configure Zotero.

Zotero can be used without an account but creating an online account will allow you to sync and access your library from anywhere. You will aslo be able to join groups and backup your attached files. Creating a Zotero account is free.

Chapter . Collections

Items in Zotero libraries can be organized with collections and tags. Both organizational methods have unique advantages and features. Experiment with both to see what works best for your own workflow.
Creating a New Collection
You can create a new collection to help organize the items in your library such as for a project or a paper.
Creating Subcollections
You can create subcollections within your top-level collection.
Adding Existing Items to Collections
You can add existing items from your library to collections in order to help organize items into collections where they fit best.
Adding New Items to Collections
You can add new items to collections to help organize your library. Find an item you would like to save, and then add it to the collections you see fit.
Renaming Collections
You can rename collections in order to best represent the collected items.
Deleting Collections
You may delete a collection when you no longer wish to use it.
Deleting Items from a Collection
You can delete an item from a collection should you decide you no longer need the item.
Removing Items from a Collection
You can remove items from a collection should you decide it no longer belongs in that collection.
Moving Items Between Collections
You can move items between collections in order to place items in the collections that best represent the their content.
Locating Items in a Collection
You can locate items once they are placed in collections.
Special Collections
Special collections are collections that have additional features such as "Duplicate Items" and "Unfiled Items".
Enabling Recursive Collections
Enabling recursive collections allows for items that are added to subcollections to also appear in the parent collection.

Tags are labels that users can use to categorize items in their libraries.

div.p: Zotero is a free tool to help you collect, organize and share research.

Zotero is a free multi-platform software that helps you collect research easily from different sources. It automatically recognizes articles from sources like JSTOR and can add them to custom libraries with a single click. You can organize your libraries by sorting them into collections and tagging them with keywords. Zotero also makes it easy to collaborate by sharing libraries with other users and providing options for synchronizing your data. Zotero can integrate into your browse or word processor for a seamless user experience.

Since Zotero 5.0, Zotero for Firefox and Zotero Standalone have been replacef by a single version of Zotero that is compatible with all browsers. Mozilla has disconitnued its extension framework, on which Zotero for Firefox was based, instead opting for the WebExtensions framework. This limits how much the extension can modify the browser experience, but allows the Zotero team to create a more unified experience available across multiple browsers. This means you will need to be running Zotero in the background when using the Zotero Connector (on page ) plugin to save articles being viewed in your browser.

div.p: Data Syncing merges the Zotero content on your local computer with the content on the Zotero servers.

Data syncing allows you to keep your library items, notes, links and tags (but not file attachements) consistent across multiple devices. With data syncing, you can pick up on work that you started on a different computer and view your library online without needing to have Zotero installed.
Data syncing allows you to pick up where you left off on a different computer.

li.span: Click Edit in the Zotero menu bar and open the Preferences.
Click on the Sync pane and enter your Zotero account data.
Click Set Up Syncing to turn on automatic data syncing.
li.div: Automatic data syncing will only sync data like item entries in your library. To also sync file attachments, you will need to activate file syncing (on page ) separately.

div.p: Items in Zotero libraries can be organized with collections and tags. Both organizational methods have unique advantages and features. Experiment with both to see what works best for your own workflow.

Collections allow hierarchical organization of items into groups and subgroups. The same item can belong to multiple collections and subcollections in your library at the same item. Collections are useful for filing items in meaningful groups (e.g., items for a particular project, from a specific source, on a specific topic, or for a particular course).
div.div: Note: Collections are not portable. Copying items between Zotero libraries (My Library and group libraries) will transfer their tags, but not their collection placements.

div.p: You can create a new collection to help organize the items in your library such as for a project or a paper.

section.p: Collections are useful for filing items in meaningful groups. You can create new Collections however you see fit.

li.span: Create a new collection

You can also right-click on My Library or the name of a Group library and choose New Collection to add a new collection

li.span: Title your new collection and click OK

div.section: The new collection will appear as a folder under My Library or the selected Group library.

div.p: You can create subcollections within your top-level collection.

section.p: You can store items in subcollections just as you would in a top-level collection. Adding an item to a subcollection does not duplicate the item, even if it appears in another collection.

ul.li: Drag an existing collection onto another collection
Right-click an existing collection and select New Subcollection

div.div: You can convert a subcollection into a top-level collection by dragging it out of the collection and dropping it into empty space in the left Zotero pane.

div.p: You can add existing items from your library to collections in order to help organize items into collections where they fit best.

section.p: Adding existing items to collections is useful when organizing items that you have previously collected into new collections.

li.span: Select an existing item(s) from your library in the center pane

li.div: By default, the items will be added to the new collection but won't be removed from their original location.

div.p: You can add new items to collections to help organize your library. Find an item you would like to save, and then add it to the collections you see fit.

section.p: Adding new items to collections is useful when you are working with new items and you need to catalog them somewhere for later use.

li.span: Locate a new item from the web
Select the collection you want to save the item to
Click on the Zotero Save Button in your browser

div.p: You can rename collections in order to best represent the collected items.

section.p: You may want to rename a collection as your collection grows in order to better represent the items within it. It is not suggested to rename collections too frequently.

li.span: Right-click on the collection
Select "Rename Collection" and type in the new name of the collection
li.div: Collections are sorted alphabetically in your library. You can use punctuation marks to sort collections to the top of the list.

div.p: You may delete a collection when you no longer wish to use it.

section.p: Deleting collections is useful when you no longer have a use for a collection. Deleting a collection will also delete all of the subcollections in it, but not the items in them. Items are still accessible by clicking on My Library or the Group library name.

li.span: Right-click on the collection
Select "Delete Collection"

div.section: The collection and all of its subcollections will have been removed from your library.

div.p: You can delete an item from a collection should you decide you no longer need the item.

section.p: Deleting an item from a collection removes the item from your Zotero library entirely. This may be useful for users needing to make space in their libraries.

li.span: Select the item(s) in the collection

li.div: When My Library or a Group library name is selected in the left Zotero pane, pressing the Delete key will also move items to the trash. When a collection or subcollection is selected, press Cmd/Ctrl-Delete to move the items directly to the trash.

div.p: You can remove items from a collection should you decide it no longer belongs in that collection.

section.p: Removing items from a collection gives you the ability to customize which items are in your collections. If you no longer wish for an item to be included in a collection, you can remove it without deletingthe item.

div.p: Special collections are collections that have additional features such as "Duplicate Items" and "Unfiled Items".

Special collections offer additinal services to the user through automated behaviors. When items do not fit within the guidelines of an existing collections, Special Collections often provide a suitable location.

section.p: The My Publications special collection allows you to share your own research work (including items, notes, and attachment files) publicly with the world. When you delete an item, they are moved to the Trash special collection. By default, items remain in the Trash for 30 days, after which they are deleted permanently.

section.p: By default, items added to a subcollection do not automatically appear in the parent collection(s). Enabling recursive collections is useful if you would like them to appear twice, once in the parent collection and once in the subcollection. Recursive collections are not currently available for the online library at zotero.org.

div.p: Tags are labels that users can use to categorize items in their libraries.

Tags (often called keywords in other contexts) allow for detailed characterization of an item. You can tag items based on their topics, methods, status, ratings, or even based on your own workflow (e.g., to-read). Items can have as many tags as you like, and you can filter your library (or a specific collection) to show items having a specific set of one or more tags.
div.div: Note: Tags are portable. Copying items between Zotero libraries (My Library and group libraries) will transfer their tags.

As you apply filters, the list of tags in the tag selector will be updated to show only the tags assigned to currently visible items. The tag selector is located at the bottom of the left Zotero pane.

div.p: Full-text PDF indexing allows embedded text within PDFs to be searched with Quick Search (via the Everything option) and Advanced Search (via Attachment Content).

You can control how much text in a PDF is indexed in the Search pane of Zotero preferences (default: 500000 characters, 100 pages). Indexing happens automatically in the background when Zotero is idle. You can remove indexed text with the Clear Index button or re-create the index from scratch using the Rebuild Index button. You can check the index status of any PDF attachment by selecting the attachment item in the Zotero library and looking at the Indexed: field in the right pane.

If an item isn't being indexed (e.g., if it is not showing up not showing up an 'Everything' Quick Search), verify that the item has searchable text and that the text is properly stored in the PDF (e.g., try to copy text out of the document and ensure that it is high quality). If the PDF has valid text, rebuild the item's index by right-clicking on it and choosing Reindex Item. If you are still having issues, please ask a question on the Zotero forums.
div.div: Note: At this time, only PDF full text content (and plain text files) can be indexed by Zotero. Other document types (e.g., .docx, .odt, .epub) cannot be indexed by Zotero.
